(Actually 106 including this one!)

For about a year, Iâ€™ve made the effort two or three times a week to design posts that attract comment, to invite engagement, and to pause all my usual updates for a while.

Results:

An average of 5,000 views, ranging from just three under 1,000 (articles and videos get very low view, and promotional posts donâ€™t do as well).

11 got over 10k views, 13 got under 2k.

Top 5:  
âž„ Four quadrants of thinking threats 14,000  
âžƒ Customer insight 15,000  
âž‚ â€˜Doomed to succeedâ€™ death march projects 18,000  
âž The â€˜brown contractâ€™ 19,000  
âž€ Technical vs adaptive change 30,000

What Iâ€™ve learned:  
\> The algorithm is in charge, and they change it radically and randomly.  
I hated bowing to the algorithmâ€Šâ€”â€Šit felt like twisting and oversimplifying and dumbing down.  
Then I enjoyed itâ€Šâ€”â€Šhitting my stride, real reach, good responses.  
Then I hated it again. As they experiment, you have to chase the black box, or disappear.

\> There is good guidance out there on what worksâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut it can be a part-time job to follow it.

\> I havenâ€™t exactly got any work from itâ€Šâ€”â€Šthough I have got great responses, learning, connections, and engagement.  
And I have learned to write to the format, compress my ideas. (Theyâ€™ve just doubled the length now, though!)

\> People love  
- complexity, and images of complexity.  
- to really engage with deep ideasâ€Šâ€”â€Šand offer useful and smart responses.  
- arguments, especially with those with many followers.

\> Some of the posts I thought were absolutely the bestâ€Šâ€”â€Šsimple, insightful, engagingâ€Šâ€”â€Šdid really poorly.  
\> Some I just put out to keep things going did \*really\* well.  
\> Sometimes something I was just sharing randomly got over 10,000 views!

**Whatâ€™s your favourite post?  
What do you take from this learning?  
What do you think I should learn?**
